description: The DigitalOcean API allows you to manage Droplets and resources within the DigitalOcean cloud in a simple, programmatic way using conventional HTTP requests. The endpoints are intuitive and powerful, allowing you to easily make calls to retrieve information or to execute actions.

blocks.name: getActionsList
blocks.description: To list all of the actions that have been executed on the current account.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: page
args.info: Page number

args.name: perPage
args.info: Number of items you would like per page

blocks.name: getSingleAction
blocks.description: The result will be a JSON object with an action key.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: actionId
args.info: Action id

blocks.name: getVolumesList
blocks.description: To list all of the Block Storage volumes available on your account.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: region
args.info: May be provided as query paramater in order to restrict results to volumes available in a specific region.

blocks.name: createVolume
blocks.description: Create new volume

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: sizeGigabytes
args.info: The size of the Block Storage volume in GiB (1024^3).

args.name: name
args.info: A human-readable name for the Block Storage volume. Must be lowercase and be composed only of numbers, letters and `-`, up to a limit of 64 characters.

args.name: description
args.info: An optional free-form text field to describe a Block Storage volume.

args.name: region
args.info: The region where the Block Storage volume will be created. When setting a region, the value should be the slug identifier for the region. When you query a Block Storage volume, the entire region object will be returned. Should not be specified with a snapshot_id.

args.name: snapshotId
args.info: The unique identifier for the volume snapshot from which to create the volume. Should not be specified with a region_id.

blocks.name: getSingleVolume
blocks.description: Show information about a Block Storage volume

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

blocks.name: getVolumeByName
blocks.description: Retrieve information about a Block Storage volume by name.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: name
args.info: A human-readable name for the Block Storage volume. Must be lowercase and be composed only of numbers, letters and `-`, up to a limit of 64 characters.

args.name: region
args.info: May be provided as query paramater in order to restrict results to volumes available in a specific region.

blocks.name: getVolumeSnapshots
blocks.description: Retrieve the snapshots that have been created from a volume

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

args.name: page
args.info: Page number

args.name: perPage
args.info: Number of items you would like per page

blocks.name: createVolumeSnapshot
blocks.description: Create a snapshot from a volume

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

args.name: name
args.info: A human-readable name for the volume snapshot.

blocks.name: deleteVolume
blocks.description: Delete single volume

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

blocks.name: deleteVolumeByName
blocks.description: Delete single volume by name

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: name
args.info: A human-readable name for the Block Storage volume.

blocks.name: attachVolumeToDroplet
blocks.description: Attach a Block Storage volume to a Droplet.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

args.name: type
args.info: This must be `attach`

args.name: dropletId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Droplet the volume will be attached or detached from.

args.name: region
args.info: The slug identifier for the region the volume is located in.

blocks.name: attachVolumeToDropletByName
blocks.description: Attach a Block Storage volume to a Droplet using its name.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeName
args.info: The name of the Block Storage volume.

args.name: type
args.info: This must be 'attach'

args.name: dropletId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Droplet the volume will be attached or detached from.

args.name: region
args.info: The slug identifier for the region the volume is located in.

blocks.name: removeVolumeFromDroplet
blocks.description: Detach a Block Storage volume from a Droplet

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

args.name: type
args.info: This must be `detach`

args.name: dropletId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Droplet the volume will be attached or detached from.

args.name: region
args.info: The slug identifier for the region the volume is located in.

blocks.name: removeVolumeFromDropletByName
blocks.description: Detach a Block Storage volume from a Droplet using its name

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeName
args.info: The name of the Block Storage volume.

args.name: type
args.info: This must be 'detach'

args.name: dropletId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Droplet the volume will be attached or detached from.

args.name: region
args.info: The slug identifier for the region the volume is located in.

blocks.name: resizeVolume
blocks.description: Resize a Block Storage volume.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

args.name: type
args.info: This must be `resize`

args.name: sizeGigabytes
args.info: The new size of the Block Storage volume in GiB (1024^3).

args.name: region
args.info: The slug identifier for the region the volume is located in.

blocks.name: getVolumeActions
blocks.description: Retrieve all actions that have been executed on a volume.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

args.name: page
args.info: Page number

args.name: perPage
args.info: Number of items you would like per page

blocks.name: getSingleVolumeAction
blocks.description: Retrieve the status of a volume action

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: volumeId
args.info: The unique identifier for the Block Storage volume.

args.name: actionId
args.info: A unique numeric ID that can be used to identify and reference an action.

blocks.name: createCertificate
blocks.description: Upload a new SSL certificate

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: name
args.info: A unique human-readable name referring to a certificate.

args.name: privateKey
args.info: The contents of a PEM-formatted private-key corresponding to the SSL certificate.

args.name: leafCertificate
args.info: The contents of a PEM-formatted public SSL certificate.

args.name: certificateChain
args.info: The full PEM-formatted trust chain between the certificate authority's certificate and your domain's SSL certificate.

blocks.name: getSingleCertificate
blocks.description: Show information about an existing certificate.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: certificateId
args.info: A unique ID that can be used to identify and reference a certificate.

blocks.name: getAllCertificates
blocks.description: List all of the certificates available on your account.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

blocks.name: deleteCertificate
blocks.description: Delete a specific certificate.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: certificateId
args.info: A unique ID that can be used to identify and reference a certificate.

blocks.name: getAllDomains
blocks.description: Retrieve a list of all of the domains in your account.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

blocks.name: createDomain
blocks.description: Create a new domain.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: name
args.info: The domain name to add to the DigitalOcean DNS management interface. The name must be unique in DigitalOcean's DNS system. The request will fail if the name has already been taken.

args.name: ipAddress
args.info: This attribute contains the IP address you want the domain to point to.

blocks.name: getSingleDomain
blocks.description: Get details about a specific domain.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: domain
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

blocks.name: deleteDomain
blocks.description: Delete a domain.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: domain
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

blocks.name: getAllDomainRecords
blocks.description: Get a listing of all records configured for a domain.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: domain
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

blocks.name: createDomainRecord
blocks.description: Create an existing record.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: domain
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

args.name: type
args.info: The record type (A, MX, CNAME, AAAA, TXT, NS, SRV).

args.name: name
args.info: The host name, alias, or service being defined by the record.

args.name: data
args.info: Variable data depending on record type. See the [Domain Records]() section for more detail on each record type.

args.name: priority
args.info: The priority of the host (for SRV and MX records. null otherwise).

args.name: port
args.info: The port that the service is accessible on (for SRV records only. null otherwise).

args.name: ttl
args.info: This value is the time to live for the record, in seconds. This defines the time frame that clients can cache queried information before a refresh should be requested. If not set, the default value is 1800.

args.name: weight
args.info: The weight of records with the same priority (for SRV records only. null otherwise).

blocks.name: getSingleDomainRecord
blocks.description: Retrieve a specific domain record.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: domain
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

args.name: recordId
args.info: A unique identifier for each domain record.

blocks.name: updateDomainRecord
blocks.description: Update an existing record.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: domain
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

args.name: recordId
args.info: A unique identifier for each domain record.

args.name: type
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

args.name: name
args.info: The host name, alias, or service being defined by the record.

args.name: data
args.info: Variable data depending on record type. See the [Domain Records]() section for more detail on each record type.

args.name: priority
args.info: The priority of the host (for SRV and MX records. null otherwise).

args.name: port
args.info: The port that the service is accessible on (for SRV records only. null otherwise).

args.name: ttl
args.info: This value is the time to live for the record, in seconds. This defines the time frame that clients can cache queried information before a refresh should be requested. If not set, the default value is 1800.

args.name: weight
args.info: The weight of records with the same priority (for SRV records only. null otherwise).

blocks.name: deleteDomainRecord
blocks.description: Retrieve a specific domain record.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: domain
args.info: The name of the domain itself. This should follow the standard domain format of domain.TLD. For instance, example.com is a valid domain name.

args.name: recordId
args.info: A unique identifier for each domain record.

blocks.name: createDroplet
blocks.description: Create a new Droplet.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: name
args.info: The human-readable string you wish to use when displaying the Droplet name. The name, if set to a domain name managed in the DigitalOcean DNS management system, will configure a PTR record for the Droplet. The name set during creation will also determine the hostname for the Droplet in its internal configuration.

args.name: region
args.info: The unique slug identifier for the region that you wish to deploy in.

args.name: size
args.info: The unique slug identifier for the size that you wish to select for this Droplet. Example: 512mb

args.name: image
args.info: The image ID of a public or private image, or the unique slug identifier for a public image. This image will be the base image for your Droplet. Example: ubuntu-14-04-x64

args.name: sshKeys
args.info: An array containing the IDs or fingerprints of the SSH keys that you wish to embed in the Droplet's root account upon creation.

structure.name: id
structure.info: SSH key id

args.name: backups
args.info: A boolean indicating whether automated backups should be enabled for the Droplet. Automated backups can only be enabled when the Droplet is created.

args.name: ipv6
args.info: A boolean indicating whether IPv6 is enabled on the Droplet.

args.name: privateNetworking
args.info: A boolean indicating whether private networking is enabled for the Droplet. Private networking is currently only available in certain regions.

args.name: userData
args.info: A string containing 'user data' which may be used to configure the Droplet on first boot, often a 'cloud-config' file or Bash script. It must be plain text and may not exceed 64 KiB in size.

args.name: monitoring
args.info: A boolean indicating whether to install the DigitalOcean agent for monitoring.

args.name: volumes
args.info: A flat array including the unique string identifier for each Block Storage volume to be attached to the Droplet. At the moment a volume can only be attached to a single Droplet.

structure.name: id
structure.info: Volume id

args.name: tags
args.info: A flat array of tag names as strings to apply to the Droplet after it is created. Tag names can either be existing or new tags.

structure.name: id
structure.info: Tag id

blocks.name: createMultiplyDroplets
blocks.description: Create a new Droplet.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: names
args.info: An array of human human-readable strings you wish to use when displaying the Droplet name. Each name, if set to a domain name managed in the DigitalOcean DNS management system, will configure a PTR record for the Droplet. Each name set during creation will also determine the hostname for the Droplet in its internal configuration.

structure.name: name
structure.info: Each name

args.name: region
args.info: The unique slug identifier for the region that you wish to deploy in.

args.name: size
args.info: The unique slug identifier for the size that you wish to select for this Droplet.

args.name: image
args.info: The image ID of a public or private image, or the unique slug identifier for a public image. This image will be the base image for your Droplet.

args.name: sshKeys
args.info: An array containing the IDs or fingerprints of the SSH keys that you wish to embed in the Droplet's root account upon creation.

structure.name: id
structure.info: SSH key id

args.name: backups
args.info: A boolean indicating whether automated backups should be enabled for the Droplet. Automated backups can only be enabled when the Droplet is created.

args.name: ipv6
args.info: A boolean indicating whether IPv6 is enabled on the Droplet.

args.name: privateNetworking
args.info: A boolean indicating whether private networking is enabled for the Droplet. Private networking is currently only available in certain regions.

args.name: userData
args.info: A string containing 'user data' which may be used to configure the Droplet on first boot, often a 'cloud-config' file or Bash script. It must be plain text and may not exceed 64 KiB in size.

args.name: monitoring
args.info: A boolean indicating whether to install the DigitalOcean agent for monitoring.

args.name: volumes
args.info: A flat array including the unique string identifier for each Block Storage volume to be attached to the Droplet. At the moment a volume can only be attached to a single Droplet.

structure.name: id
structure.info: Volume id

args.name: tags
args.info: A flat array of tag names as strings to apply to the Droplet after it is created. Tag names can either be existing or new tags.

structure.name: id
structure.info: Tag id

args.name: name
args.info: A human-readable name for a Firewall.

args.name: inboundRules
args.info: An object specifying the inbound access rules for a Firewall (see example below).

structure.name: protocol
structure.info: The type of traffic to be allowed. This may be one of `tcp`, `udp`, or `icmp`.

structure.name: ports
structure.info: The ports on which traffic will be allowed specified as a string containing a single port, a range (e.g. `8000-9000`), or `all` to open all ports for a protocol.

structure.name: sources
structure.info: An object specifying locations from which inbound traffic will be accepted. (See below for the available keys and the types.).

args.name: outboundRules
args.info: An object specifying the outbound access rules for a Firewall (see table below).

structure.name: destinations
structure.info: An object specifying locations to which outbound traffic that will be allowed. (See below for the available keys and the types.).

blocks.name: createLoadBalancer
blocks.description: Create a new Load Balancer instance.

args.name: accessToken
args.info: Your Digital Ocean access token

args.name: name
args.info: A human-readable name for a Load Balancer instance.

args.name: algorithm
args.info: The load balancing algorithm used to determine which backend Droplet will be selected by a client. It must be either `round_robin` or `least_connections`. The default value is `round_robin`.

args.name: region
args.info: The region where the Load Balancer instance will be located. When setting a region, the value should be the slug identifier for the region. When you query a Load Balancer, an entire region object will be returned.

args.name: forwardingRules
args.info: An array of objects specifying the forwarding rules for a Load Balancer. At least one forwarding rule is required when creating a new Load Balancer instance (see table below).

structure.name: entry_protocol
structure.info: The protocol used for traffic to the Load Balancer. The possible values are: `http`, `https`, or `tcp`.

structure.name: entry_port
structure.info: An integer representing the port on which the Load Balancer instance will listen.

structure.name: target_protocol
structure.info: The protocol used for traffic from the Load Balancer to the backend Droplets. The possible values are: `http`, `https`, or `tcp`.

structure.name: target_port
structure.info: An integer representing the port on the backend Droplets to which the Load Balancer will send traffic.

structure.name: certificate_id
structure.info: The ID of the TLS certificate to be used for SSL termination.

structure.name: tls_passthrough
structure.info: A boolean value indicating whether SSL encrypted traffic will be passed through to the backend Droplets. The defaults value is false.

args.name: healthCheck
args.info: An object specifying health check settings for the Load Balancer. If omitted, default values will be provided (see table below).

structure.name: protocol
structure.info: The protocol used for health checks sent to the backend Droplets. The possible values are `http` or `tcp`.

structure.name: port
structure.info: An integer representing the port on the backend Droplets on which the health check will attempt a connection.

structure.name: path
structure.info: The path on the backend Droplets to which the Load Balancer instance will send a request. The default value is `/`.

structure.name: check_interval_seconds
structure.info: The number of seconds between between two consecutive health checks. If not specified, the default value is `10`.

structure.name: response_timeout_seconds
structure.info: The number of seconds the Load Balancer instance will wait for a response until marking a health check as failed. If not specified, the default value is `5`.

structure.name: unhealthy_threshold
structure.info: The number of times a health check must fail for a backend Droplet to be marked `unhealthy` and be removed from the pool. If not specified, the default value is `3`.

structure.name: healthy_threshold
structure.info: The number of times a health check must pass for a backend Droplet to be marked `healthy` and be re-added to the pool. If not specified, the default value is `5`.

args.name: stickySessions
args.info: An object specifying sticky sessions settings for the Load Balancer (see table below).

structure.name: type
structure.info: An attribute indicating how and if requests from a client will be persistently served by the same backend Droplet. The possible values are `cookies` or `none`. If not specified, the default value is `none`.

structure.name: cookie_name
structure.info: The name to be used for the cookie sent to the client. This attribute is required when using `cookies` for the sticky sessions type.

structure.name: cookie_ttl_seconds
structure.info: The number of seconds until the cookie set by the Load Balancer expires. This attribute is required when using `cookies` for the sticky sessions type.

args.name: redirectHttpToHttps
args.info: A boolean value indicating whether HTTP requests to the Load Balancer on port 80 will be redirected to HTTPS on port 443. Default value is false.

args.name: dropletIds
args.info: An array containing the IDs of the Droplets to be assigned to the Load Balancer.

structure.name: id
structure.info: Droplet id
